context: In the 13C-urea breath test, an enrichment in the 13CO2/12CO2ratio over a baseline (pre-drink) sample is consistent with H. pylori infection (7–9). The principal differences among reported 13C-urea breath tests center on the amount of 13C-urea used and the type or presence of a test meal. In fact, there has been considerable discussion in the literature over the optimal format of the 13C-urea breath test in an attempt to standardize the test (10,11). For instance, it has been suggested that factors such as test meal composition and prior versus concurrent ingestion of citric acid (relative to labeled urea), are of relevance to the rate of gastric emptying and, by extension, to the residence time of urea in the stomach. It has been theorized that increased residence time allows for enhanced interaction between the substrate and the H. pylori organism, and hence, increased sensitivity. Radioactive (14C) versions of the urea breath test are also available (12–14). Although “low dose” formats of the radioactive test have been commercialized there still exist concerns about safe handling, administration and disposal of the isotope as well as the appropriateness of administration to children, pregnant women, or women of childbearing years.
